awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase II:  Scalable Detector for Multiple-Input Multiple-Output (MIMO) Communication Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this project lies in its ability to implement multiple-input
multiple-output (MIMO) detectors of any size. This, in turn, impacts the broad needs of wireless
communications industry that is always in search of more efficient use of the scarce spectral resources.
Since its invention 15 years ago, MIMO has been included in all wireless standards, e.g. WiFi,
WiMAX, and LTE. As of today, MIMO products of sizes up to 4x4 (i.e. 4 transmit and 4 receive
antennas) have appeared in the market, while the most recent standards, such as IEEE 802.11ac WiFi
and LTE-Advanced cellular, have specified MIMO sizes as large as 8x8. For WiFi this can mean more
effective hot-spots in public and workplace settings. For cellular this can mean improved connectivity
in rural areas with fewer base-station towers, having a positive economic impact. Industry activities
that attempt to build larger MIMO systems such as 16x16 are occurring. Massive MIMO networks with
more than 100 antennas at the base stations have recently been proposed for 5G cellular and beyond.
These trends indicate a large market opportunity for the scalable MIMO technology that this project
builds upon.

This Small Business Technology Transfer Research (STTR) Phase 2 project plans to develop and
commercialize a set of intellectual property (IP) software-codes/IP-cores related to multiple-input
multiple-output (MIMO) communications. These cores address the needs of wireless chipset
manufacturers. The main hurdle in the design and implementation of MIMO systems is their
complexity which drives cost and power consumption. The complexity of an optimal MIMO detector
grows exponentially with the number of transmit antennas. The same is true for most of the near
optimal MIMO detectors that have been suggested in the literature and adopted by industry. This
limitation has been the main impediment in developing commercial MIMO systems that support larger
array sizes with increased range and data rate. This project adopts a novel technology that achieves near
optimal performance having complexity that only grows linearly with the number of transmit antennas.
It thus can be used to implement MIMO systems of any size, at an affordable complexity.

por.por_cntn:
In this SBIR/STTR Phase II project we set out to complete initial commercialization of a MIMO technology originally developed at University of Utah under other NSF federal grants. Our novel method can achieve optimal performance while having low complexity for four to eight antennas. This has applications in WiFi, LTE, and 5G cellular communications where larger multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) sizes can dramatically increase spectral efficiency, speeds, reliability, number of users/devices connected, and range.

During the award, we completed all of our major objectives to expand on our initial 4-antenna by 4-antenna (4x4) and 8x8 MIMO detector solutions. Additionally, we made three inventions, patent pending, which have used modern machine learning techniques to greatly improve performance while reducing our cost/complexity by a further ~10x. To validate our designs we made large improvements to our custom 8x8 high performance MIMO testbed which sends real packets over the air to measure true performance, see attached figures. We also developed an iPhone sized 8-antenna array to demonstrate 8x8 MIMO in a realistic and useful form factor, see attached figures.

The work executed underneath this grant is having a positive effect on the fields of electrical engineering and wireless communications. Achieving near optimal performance on MIMO antenna communications has been a goal for decades, and although great progress has been made there is still a significant difference between real-world performance and optimal maximum likelihood performance with more than three antennas. This work has closed that gap and shown extremely high performance at up to eight antennas with an affordable silicon cost. There are currently two peer-reviewed journal articles in progress which will greatly enhance the body of knowledge on this subject.

One of the important national objectives is to provide broadband internet to rural and economically disadvantaged areas. This is a difficult problem to solve because the cost of installing the typical cable or fiber based infrastructure to distribute internet, as it?s done in more urban areas, is cost prohibitive when the population density or number of subscribers is low. There are attempts at distributing broadband wirelessly, but these are generally very expensive and suffer from poor performance. This is because the current technology does not use the available spectrum efficiently enough to allow high numbers of users and high data rates, which drives cost up and performance down. A key emerging technology which is included in the LTE/5G cellular standard is spatial multiplexing MIMO. The most recent standard allows up to 8 spatial streams, meaning the spectrum efficiency can possibly increase by eight times, enabling eight times as many users to be simultaneously connected or eight times as much data to be transmitted. This technology could be a critical step in enabling the proliferation of wireless broadband internet.
